study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of soy lecithin in high-forage diets on performance, serum lipid metabolites, and carcass characteristics of growing ram lambs.
results_summary: Soy lecithin increased energy intake and serum lipid concentrations, resulting in fatter carcasses with greater dressing percentage and subcutaneous fat thickness. Canola seed had little effect compared to soy lecithin.
population_specificity: Growing ram lambs (Hampshire- or Suffolk-sired, weaned at 60 days, average initial weight 23.6 kg).
effective_dosage: 4.9% deoiled soy lecithin (of dietary dry matter).
study_duration: Until lambs reached an average final body weight of 52.1 kg (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining high intensity ultrasound (HIU) and high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) with transglutaminase (TGase) could improve the encapsulation, stability, and controlled release of riboflavin in soy protein isolate (SPI) cold gels.
results_summary: The HIU-HHP combined treatment enhanced the structural and physicochemical properties of SPI cold gels, improving riboflavin encapsulation efficiency, stability, and sustained release. It also promoted targeted riboflavin release in simulated intestinal fluid, increasing bioaccessibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the regulatory changes of hepatic miRNAs induced by enzyme-treated soybean protein in largemouth bass exposed to oxytetracycline.
results_summary: The study found that enzyme-treated soybean protein modulated miRNA expression in largemouth bass, with the ETSP group showing up-regulation of 36 miRNAs and down-regulation of 13 miRNAs compared to the OTC group. Nine key miRNAs were identified as protective against oxytetracycline-induced liver effects, with cellular lipid metabolism and propanoate pathways highlighted as significant.
population_specificity: Largemouth bass

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and biocompatibility of cellulose acetate functionalized with soy protein acid hydrolysate (CA/SPAH) for manufacturing nerve guide conduits (NGCs) suitable for peripheral nerve regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that CA/SPAH NGCs were easily customizable, bacteria-free, and exhibited initial biocompatibility with Schwann cells, showing cell adhesion after 5 days. The conduits had uniform wall thickness, flexibility, and were suturable, making them suitable for nerve regeneration studies.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Schwann cells (SCL 4.1/F7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ultrasonic-thermal synergistic treatments combined with vacuum degassing could reduce the beany flavor of soy protein isolate (SPI) by altering its protein structure and flavor-binding ability.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasonic-thermal synergistic treatments significantly reduced volatile compounds (e.g., hexanal, (E)-2-hexenal, 1-octen-3-ol) and eliminated others (e.g., (E)-2-nonenal, 2-pentylfuran), while altering protein secondary structure and surface hydrophobicity, which correlated with flavor reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on SPI, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasound treatment on soy protein isolate (SPI) structure and its interaction with sodium alginate (SA) to improve the quality of plant-based meat substitutes.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment promoted protein aggregation and improved fiber spinnability, while Ca2+ ions interacted with SA during coagulation. The treated fibers showed higher water-holding capacity and better mechanical properties without compromising thermal stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a bilayer wound dressing containing soy protein isolate (SPI) in promoting wound healing and its potential for clinical use.
results_summary: The Cel/Pec-SPI-P dressing demonstrated excellent cell adhesion, migration, and angiogenesis, with in vivo experiments showing faster wound healing, epidermal layer formation, blood vessel generation, and collagen deposition. The dressing was non-cytotoxic and exhibited antibacterial activity.
population_specificity: Human keratinocyte cells and in vivo wound models (specific population not detailed).
study_duration: 7 days (weight loss measurement), in vivo duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat treatment and transglutaminase (TG) crosslinking of soybean isolate (SPI) particles could improve the freeze-thaw stability of Pickering emulsions for use in frozen foods like ice cream.
results_summary: Heat-treated and TG-crosslinked SPI (HSPI-TG-40) produced Pickering emulsions with the highest freeze-thaw stability, lowest ice crystal formation temperature, and improved texture in plant-based ice cream compared to untreated SPI (NSPI).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro/lab-based study).

study_goal: The researchers investigated the impact of calcium chloride (CaCl2) and magnesium chloride (MgCl2) on the physical and chemical properties of a model milk formulation after thermal treatment.
results_summary: Increasing concentrations of CaCl2 or MgCl2 led to higher viscosity and median particle size in the milk emulsion after heating, with CaCl2 having a slightly stronger effect. The zeta potential decreased with higher ionic strength, and emulsion stability varied significantly between high and low salt concentrations.
population_specificity: Model milk formulation (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Various concentrations, with significant effects observed at or above 5.0 mM.
study_duration: Not specified (thermal treatment and analysis were performed, but duration of intervention is unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of combining mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) with soy protein and β-chitin scaffolds for chronic wound healing.
results_summary: The combined therapy improved cell retention, viability, and migration of fibroblasts and keratinocytes, promoted angiogenesis, and reduced wound healing time in vivo.
population_specificity: Chronic wound patients (in vivo model implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ultrasonic and thermal treatments on the structural, functional, and flavor properties of soy protein isolate (SPI).
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment improved SPI's solubility, emulsifying, and foaming properties by inducing structural changes, while both treatments reduced beany flavor compounds. Structural changes from ultrasonic treatment correlated strongly with functional properties but weakly with flavor, whereas thermal treatment showed the opposite trend.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on SPI)
effective_dosage: 350 W ultrasonic power, 150 s thermal treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different freezing temperatures affect the structural and emulsification properties of soy protein isolate (SPI).
results_summary: Freezing at -5 ℃ and -20 ℃ loosened SPI structure and increased exposure of certain amino acids, while lower temperatures (-40 ℃ and -80 ℃) altered surface hydrophobicity, sulfhydryl groups, and disulfide bonds. Emulsification performance of SPI decreased after freezing treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on SPI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oral supplementation with soy protein isolate and isoflavones (SPII) on photoaging components (wrinkles, dyspigmentation) and skin biophysical measures (hydration, sebum excretion) in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: SPII supplementation significantly reduced wrinkle severity at 16 and 24 weeks, decreased facial pigment intensity at 24 weeks, and increased skin hydration, with no significant changes in sebum production compared to the casein group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with Fitzpatrick skin types I, II, and III.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different heat treatment conditions affect off-flavor compounds in soy protein isolate (SPI) by examining lipid oxidation, Maillard reaction, and protein structural changes.
results_summary: Higher off-flavor concentrations were found in untreated and 65℃ treated SPI due to enzymatic lipid oxidation. Heating at 75℃ to 95℃ initially increased off-flavors due to Maillard reaction and protein denaturation, but prolonged heating at 95℃ reduced off-flavors as larger molecular weight aggregates formed.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on soy protein isolate)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (heat treatment conditions: 65℃ for 30 min, 75℃ for 15 min, 95℃ for 2, 15, and 30 min)
study_duration: Varies by heat treatment condition (2-30 minutes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dynamic microfluidic-assisted transglutaminase modification improves the structural and functional properties of soy protein isolate-chitosan adducts, particularly their antioxidant activity after in vitro digestion.
results_summary: The study found that dynamic microfluidic-assisted treatment significantly improved the binding degree (31.97%) and solubility (66.25%) of SPI-CS adducts, reduced particle size, and enhanced antioxidant activity (ABTS and DPPH radical scavenging rates and reducing power) compared to TGase modification alone.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Not specified (pressure treatment at 400 bar, twice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a hydroxyethyl cellulose/soy protein isolate (HSSC) sponge capping conduit could effectively prevent neuroma formation and promote nerve rejuvenation in rats.
results_summary: The HSSC conduit reduced autotomy scores, mitigated inflammatory invasions and collagen overdeposition, and enhanced the expression of myelin growth-linked genes (Krox20, MPZ, and MAG) compared to the no capping group. It acted as a physical barrier to inflammation and provided a favorable microenvironment for nerve recovery.
population_specificity: Rats with sciatic nerve injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the percentage of soy protein (SP) intake affects renal function and glucose/lipid metabolism in patients with type 2 diabetic nephropathy (T2DN).
results_summary: A 35% SP diet was most effective in improving renal function markers (e.g., 24hUTP, Scr, BUN, GFR) and glycolipid metabolism (e.g., CHO, LDL-C) compared to 0% SP, though heterogeneity and bias concerns were noted. Both 35% and 100% SP diets outperformed no SP in T2DN patients.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetic nephropathy (T2DN).
effective_dosage: 35% and 100% SP diets (percentage of total protein intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sous-vide processing could transform low-moisture textured soy protein (TSP) into a high-moisture product with meat-like texture.
results_summary: Sous-vide treatment maintained ~70% moisture, altered microstructure, reduced hardness, and improved protein secondary structure, achieving texture similar to chicken breast after 24h at 90℃.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on TSP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent of protein oxidation in soybean meal (SBM) and its correlation with extraction methods, non-protein components, and environmental factors.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in protein oxidation, lipidic aldehydes, and antioxidants between solvent-extracted (SSBM) and mechanically extracted (MSBM) soybean meal. Protein carbonyl content correlated positively with lipid parameters and negatively with phenolic antioxidants, indicating oxidation impacts.
population_specificity: Soybean meal samples from commercial producers across the United States (2020-2021).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cysteine concentration affects the viscosity of soy protein isolate (SPI)-based film-forming solutions and the physicochemical properties of SPI films.
results_summary: Adding 1 mmol/L cysteine reduced the viscosity of the film-forming solution and decreased film solubility, while higher cysteine concentrations (4-8 mmol/L) increased water vapor permeability and contact angle but decreased elongation at break. Cysteine crystallization was observed on the film surface at higher concentrations.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the ice recrystallization inhibition (IRI) activity of soy protein isolate (SPI) hydrolysates and analyze the impact of molecular weight and enzyme specificity on this activity.
results_summary: All SPI hydrolysates showed IRI activity, reducing ice crystal diameter by 57-29% compared to native SPI. The most effective fraction (F1, 4-14 kDa) achieved a 52% reduction at a lower concentration (2%), and vibrational sum frequency generation (VSFG) revealed differences in molecular interactions at the water/air interface that may explain IRI activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nanocompositing curcumin with soy protein isolate (SPI) and pectin (PE) could improve its stability, bioavailability, and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that SPI-Cur-PE nanocomposites exhibited slower release in simulated gastrointestinal conditions, higher photostability, and thermal stability compared to free curcumin. The nanocomposites also demonstrated scavenging activity for ABTS and DPPH radicals.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 0.6 mg curcumin, 4 mg PE, at pH 7

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of soy protein isolate (SPI)-xylose conjugates heated at different times on the viability and stability of probiotics during microencapsulation.
results_summary: SPI-xylose Maillard reaction products improved probiotic viability during spray drying, enhanced gastrointestinal digestion resistance, and provided better storability compared to non-heated mixtures. The microcapsules also had smaller particle sizes and greater intestinal digestion tolerance.
population_specificity: Probiotics (specific bacterial strains not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize soy protein isolate (SPI) extraction using ultrasound treatment and compare its yield, purity, and functional properties with microwave, enzymatic, and conventional extraction methods.
results_summary: Ultrasound-extracted SPI showed higher yield (24.17%) and protein purity (91.6%) with improved functional properties (40%-50% increase in water/oil binding, emulsion, and foaming properties) compared to other methods. Structural and thermal analyses indicated amorphous structure, secondary changes, and high thermal resistance in ultrasound-extracted SPI.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on soy meal by-product).
effective_dosage: Optimized ultrasound extraction conditions: 15.38:1 liquid-solid ratio, 51.85% amplitude, 21.70°C temperature, 3.49 s pulse, 11.01 min time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modified soy protein isolate (SPI) could improve the gel quality of silver carp protein (SCP) by enhancing its structural and textural properties.
results_summary: Modified SPI, particularly at a 0.5% degree of hydrolysis, significantly improved the hardness, springiness, chewiness, cohesiveness, and water-holding capacity of SCP gel. The study also found that hydrogen bonding, disulfide bonding, and hydrophobic interactions played key roles in gel formation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on protein gels)
effective_dosage: Degree of hydrolysis (DH) of 0.5% for SPI

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cold plasma-treated soy protein isolates (SPI) combined with proanthocyanidins (PA) could improve emulsification and oxidation resistance to create stable high internal phase Pickering emulsions (HIPPEs).
results_summary: Cold plasma treatment enhanced SPI's functionalities, and combining it with PA improved emulsification and oxidation resistance, resulting in HIPPEs with high lipid oxidation inhibition (>65%), excellent stability (creaming index >80%), and superior rheological properties compared to conventional emulsions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how multiple freeze-thaw (F-T) treatments affect the physicochemical and functional properties of soy protein isolate (SPI).
results_summary: The study found that F-T treatments altered SPI's structure, increasing surface hydrophobicity, denaturation, and aggregation, while also enhancing its antioxidant capacity. The treated SPI showed increased particle size and precipitation rates, suggesting potential improvements in functional characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on soy protein isolate)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of alkali-heating treatment and proanthocyanidins conjugation on IgE-reactivity and functional attributes of soy protein 7S.
results_summary: The study found that 7S-80PC (soy protein 7S-proanthocyanidins conjugates) exhibited lower IgE-reactivity, increased antioxidant activity, and higher emulsion activity compared to heated 7S alone, but lower foaming properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the glycation degree in infant formulas, including soy-based formulas, in relation to their ingredients.
results_summary: The soy-based formula had significantly higher concentrations of arginine and arginine-derived dAGEs compared to cow-based and goat-based formulas. The study also found that protein source, composition, and carbohydrate type influence glycation levels in infant formulas.
population_specificity: Commercial infant formulas (cow-based, goat-based, and soy-based).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of soy isoflavones and soy protein on blood adiponectin and resistin levels in adults.
results_summary: The study found that soy isoflavones combined with soy protein did not significantly change serum adiponectin levels but significantly increased serum resistin levels. Further research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the in vitro antioxidant and anticholinesterase effects of textured soy protein (TSP), nuts, and raw soybeans (RS) to identify the most effective form for improving learning capacity and spatial memory.
results_summary: TSP extract (TSPE) demonstrated the greatest antioxidant and anticholinesterase effects, significantly improving memory and learning indicators at 200 mg/kg in rats, as evidenced by prolonged initial latency in the passive avoidance test and enhanced performance in the Morris water maze test.
population_specificity: Male rats with induced amnesia via scopolamine injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of amorphous soy protein aggregates (SPAA) on the structural, physicochemical, and digestive properties of potato starch.
results_summary: SPAA improved starch's short-range order and thermal stability, reduced pasting viscosity, and decreased digestibility (lowering rapid digestible starch by 18-25% and increasing resistant starch by 15-23%). Higher-temperature SPAA (SPAA130) had a more significant effect on reducing digestive rate than lower-temperature treatments.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on potato starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physicochemical properties of soy protein isolate (SPI) and carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) after dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma treatment.
results_summary: The study confirmed SPI-CMC conjugate formation after plasma treatment, showing improved emulsifying activity, stability, solubility, and smaller droplet sizes in emulsions, with the most stable results observed after 5 minutes at 18 kV.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Treatment at 16, 18, and 20 kV for 5, 10, and 15 minutes
study_duration: Up to 15 minutes of plasma treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the protein-carbohydrate complex formed between soy protein isolate and rice starch using different treatments (heat, ultrasound, combined ultrasound-heat, and mixing alone) to assess structural and functional properties.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound treatment preserved techno-functional properties better than heat treatments, with molecular docking revealing hydrogen bond interactions that enhanced protein stability. Combined sonication and heat treatment led to higher interaction between soy protein isolate and rice starch.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how ultrasound treatment affects the gel properties of soy protein isolates (SPIs) at varying salt concentrations.
results_summary: Ultrasound significantly improved gel hardness and water holding capacity (WHC) in salt-containing SPI gels, with the combination of 200 mM NaCl and 20 min of ultrasound yielding the most pronounced effects. The treatment also enhanced protein solubility, surface hydrophobicity, and molecular interactions (hydrophobic and disulfide bonds) in the gel structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on SPI gels)
effective_dosage: 200 mM NaCl combined with 20 min of ultrasound

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different preparation methods (mixing, chemical polymerization, ultrasound) on the structure and functional properties of soy protein isolate-EGCG complexes.
results_summary: Ultrasound-treated SPI-EGCG complexes (U-SE) showed the smallest particle size, highest zeta potential, and highest polyphenol binding rate, along with the strongest antioxidant activity (highest DPPH and ABTS values). Covalent binding of EGCG with SPI altered protein structure and improved stability and antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel glycoprotein (SPI-PG) derived from soy protein isolate (SPI) for encapsulating resveratrol (RES) and improving its stability, bioavailability, and therapeutic effects.
results_summary: SPI-PG-RES demonstrated superior pH, storage, and ionic stability compared to SPI-RES, significantly enhanced RES bioavailability, exhibited stronger antioxidant capacity, and was more effective in preventing DSS-induced colitis symptoms than free RES or SPI-RES.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro and animal models based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different processing methods (ultrasonic, subcritical water, microfluidization) affect the microstructure and interfacial properties of soy protein-glucan-tannic acid complexes for stabilizing Pickering high internal phase emulsions (HIPEs).
results_summary: US and DHPM 500 treatments produced ternary complexes with smaller particle sizes and compact networks, improving oil droplet capture. S-G-T (US)- and S-G-T (DHPM500)-stabilized HIPEs showed gel-like structures, good stability, and high friction initially, but after 60 days, they exhibited more uniform droplet distribution, higher viscoelasticity, and reduced friction.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how germination affects the phytochemical content, antioxidant activity, and oxidative stability of soybean oil.
results_summary: Germinated soybean oil (GSO) showed increased levels of α-tocopherol, phytosterols, and carotenoids, with no significant changes in fatty acid content. Antioxidant activity and oxidative stability were significantly enhanced, particularly in 6-day GSO.
population_specificity: Soybeans (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying pH levels during soybean oil body (SOB) extraction affect emulsion stability and the structural properties of SOB surface proteins.
results_summary: The study found that an extraction pH of 11.0 resulted in optimal SOB emulsion stability and the most significant structural changes in SOB surface proteins, including altered amino acid fractions, surface hydrophobicity, and free sulfhydryl content. Alkaline conditions also improved SOB dispersion compared to acidic or neutral conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of thermally processed (peroxidized) soybean oil on oxidative stress markers and vitamin E levels in pigs.
results_summary: Pigs fed peroxidized soybean oil showed reduced growth performance, increased oxidative stress markers (F2-isoprostanes and reactive oxygen metabolites), and decreased plasma vitamin E levels compared to those fed unheated soybean oil. However, effects on other oxidative stress markers were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Pigs (13.5 to 37.5 kg) in two experiments.
effective_dosage: 10% soybean oil (EXP 1) or 8% soybean oil (EXP 2) in corn-soybean meal-based diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different high-pressure homogenization (HPH) pressures affect the whipping characteristics of soybean oil body (SOB) cream.
results_summary: Higher HPH pressures led to smaller particle size and higher apparent viscosity, improving cream stability. The best whipping performance was achieved at 30 MPa, with sensory evaluation and PCA confirming this treatment had the highest total score.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food science application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether epoxidized soybean oil (ESO) could improve the foamability and reduce shrinkage in PBAT/PLA blends for thermal insulation applications.
results_summary: ESO grafting and CO2 treatment enhanced the crystallinity and mechanical properties of PBAT/PLA/ESO composites, resulting in stable foam structures with high expansion ratios (19.5) and low thermal conductivity (36.7 mW/m·K). The modified foam also showed improved biodegradability, degrading by 16.1% after nine weeks.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (material composition described, but no dosage frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of using synthetic amorphous silica Trisyl® to remove phytosterols from soybean oil while minimizing tocopherol losses and avoiding thermal degradation.
results_summary: The study found that the treatment reduced sterol concentration by nearly 70% under optimal conditions (10% Trisyl®, 140 °C, 90 min), with 80% oil recovery and tocopherol losses below 20%. No thermal degradation was observed.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on soybean oil, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary peroxide value (PV) and anisidine value (AnV) in peroxidized soybean oil could predict broiler performance and assess the relative bioavailability of peroxidized soybean oil.
results_summary: The study found that peroxidized soybean oil reduced broiler performance (ADG, ADFI, and GF) and had a 12-29% lower relative bioavailability compared to unheated soybean oil. Regression models showed PV and AnV could predict performance, though the variance explained was modest (27-43%).
population_specificity: Broiler chickens (7 to 35 days old) and roosters (precision-fed assay).
effective_dosage: Soybean oil added at 0, 7.5, or 15% of the diet in EXP 2.
study_duration: 28 days (7 to 35 days of age) for broilers; duration for roosters not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soybean oil and lard on neuroinflammation and brain-gut barrier integrity in mice at different dietary fat energy levels.
results_summary: At 35% fat energy, soybean oil induced more severe neuroinflammation than lard, activating the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB p65 pathway, damaging the brain-gut barrier, and altering gut microbiota (reducing Akkermansia and unclassified_f_Lachnospiraceae while increasing Dubosiella).
population_specificity: 60 8-week-old C57BL/6J mice.
effective_dosage: 15% and 35% fat energy from soybean oil or lard.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of soy protein concentrate (SPC) on amino acid digestibility, intestinal development, intestinal microorganisms, and metabolites in broilers during early nutrition.
results_summary: SPC supplementation improved intestinal development (increased gizzard and ileum weight, villus height, and muscle thickness), altered caecal microflora composition, and increased short-chain fatty acid concentrations. It also reduced jejunum weight and length and duodenal and jejunal relative lengths.
population_specificity: One-day-old Arbor Acres (AA) male broilers
effective_dosage: 12% SPC in the basal diet during the starter phase (first 10 days)
study_duration: 42 days (10-day starter phase with SPC, followed by 32-day grower and finisher phases without SPC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acid-hydrolyzed parsley extracts could enhance antioxidant activity and delay lipid oxidation in soybean oil-in-water emulsions.
results_summary: Acid hydrolysis increased polyphenol content and antioxidant activity, extending the lag phase for hexanal formation in soybean oil emulsions from 6 to 11 days, indicating improved oxidative stability.
population_specificity: Soybean oil-in-water emulsion (food system model).
effective_dosage: 400 µmol GAE/L (total phenolic content in emulsion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how the hydrolysis time of APTES affects the physicochemical properties of starch/epoxidized soybean oil (ESO) bioplastics.
results_summary: The study found that APTES hydrolysis for 4 hours optimally modified starch, enhancing interfacial adhesion and tensile properties in bioplastics. Silylation improved thermal stability and biodegradability while maintaining opacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on bioplastics).
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on hydrolysis time of APTES: 2-24 hours).
study_duration: Not specified (laboratory-based, no explicit intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high oleic soybean oil (HOSO) on milk production, body composition, and fat digestibility in lactating cows.
results_summary: HOSO did not affect dry matter intake, milk production, or component yields but increased milk fat concentration, fat digestibility, and fat deposition compared to the control diet. Multiparous cows showed increased body weight and condition with HOSO, while primiparous cows were unaffected.
population_specificity: Thirty lactating Holstein cows (16 primiparous, 14 multiparous).
effective_dosage: 1.5% of diet dry matter as HOSO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impacts of including soybean oil (SO) in quail diets on growth, lipid profile, hepatic and renal functions, immunity, and antioxidant status.
results_summary: Soybean oil at 1.5% or 2% improved body weight gain, feed conversion ratio, lipid profile, hepatic and renal functions, immunity, and antioxidant status in quail, though linseed oil had better effects.
population_specificity: 350 Japanese quail chicks (1-week-old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neurobehavioral and brain biochemical effects of soybean oil on developing mice exposed from gestation to adulthood.
results_summary: Developmental exposure to soybean oil induced body weight changes, behavioral abnormalities (reduced locomotor activity, increased anxiety), and altered motor coordination, spatial memory, and depression-like behavior in adult mice, along with oxidative stress markers in brain regions.
population_specificity: Male and female Swiss albino mice (offspring exposed from gestation to adulthood).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding soybean oil (SBO) and phytoncide oil (PO) to dairy cow diets could increase milk conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) and reduce methane emissions.
results_summary: SBO (2%) with PO (0.1%) significantly increased CLA and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in milk, reduced methane emissions, and decreased pathogenic microbes without negatively affecting milk yield or fat content (kg/day).
population_specificity: Holstein dairy cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve soybean oil and protein content, as well as yield attributes, using gamma irradiation as a mutagen.
results_summary: Gamma irradiation positively affected yield parameters, with 100 Gy increasing protein content and 200 Gy enhancing oil content. Six mutant lines showed the highest yield improvements, and four exhibited high oil, protein, and seed yield simultaneously.
population_specificity: Soybean genotypes (Giza 21, Giza 22, Giza 82, Giza 83, and 117).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether switching from pure soybean oil-based lipid emulsions to a mixed-lipid formula (4-OLE) improved clinical outcomes in pediatric patients requiring parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found that the mixed-lipid formula (4-OLE) was associated with shorter hospital length of stay and reduced urinary tract infection risk in both ICU and non-ICU pediatric patients, with no significant differences in other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 1 month to 17 years requiring parenteral nutrition in a large US academic referral center.
study_duration: Data collected from May 2016 to September 2019 (intervention switch occurred in 2017).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of glycerol monolaurate (GML) on intestinal health in large yellow croaker fed high-level soybean oil (SO) diets.
results_summary: GML supplementation (0.02%-0.04%) improved intestinal morphology, barrier function, antioxidant capacity, and reduced inflammatory markers in fish fed high-SO diets, while also modulating gut microbiota diversity.
population_specificity: Large yellow croaker (initial weight 13.05 ± 0.09 g)
effective_dosage: 0.02%, 0.04%, and 0.08% GML added to high-SO diets

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal exposure to oxidized soybean oil (OSO) causes lipid metabolism disorders in the liver and whether these effects can be transmitted or worsened in offspring.
results_summary: OSO induced liver histopathology changes, inflammation, oxidative stress, and altered gene expression related to lipid metabolism in maternal rats (F0). Similar adverse effects were observed in offspring, indicating transgenerational liver damage and disrupted fatty acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats and their offspring.
effective_dosage: Peroxide values of 200, 400, or 800 mEqO2/kg in OSO.
study_duration: Gestation and lactation periods (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether epoxidized soybean oil (ESBO) could improve the compatibility and mechanical properties of PLA-PBAT polymer blends when treated with electron-beam irradiation.
results_summary: The study found that ESBO enhanced the compatibility between PLA and PBAT, leading to significant improvements in elongation at break and thermal properties, indicating better polymer blend performance. The extraction behavior of PBAT also changed, suggesting a binding interaction with PLA.
population_specificity: Polymer blends (PLA and PBAT) treated with electron-beam irradiation.
effective_dosage: Different ratios of ESBO were used, but specific amounts were not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heating and extraction pH on the stability, digestion, and lipolysis of soybean oil body (SOB) emulsions.
results_summary: Heating affected protein hydrolysis, particle size, and lipolysis in SOB emulsions, with pH 7.0-SOB showing faster extrinsic protein hydrolysis at 60-80°C and pH 11.0-SOB exhibiting higher FFA release at 80°C. Particle sizes increased with heating but decreased after intestinal digestion, with minimal effects from different heating temperatures on final microstructures.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of soybean isoflavones and phytosterols on the formation of harmful compounds (3-MCPDE and aldehydes) in heated soybean oil.
results_summary: The study found that soybean isoflavones and phytosterols, particularly stigmasterol, significantly reduced the formation of 3-MCPDE and aldehydes in heated soybean oil. Stigmasterol also reduced glycidyl esters (GEs) and glycidol, key intermediates of 3-MCPDE, and protected fatty acids from degradation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system study)
effective_dosage: 0.4 mM of genistin, genistein, daidzein, stigmasterol, and β-sitosterol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using surface dielectric barrier discharge cold plasma (SDBDCP) for partial hydrogenation and bleaching of crude soybean oil.
results_summary: The study found that SDBDCP treatment increased saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids while reducing polyunsaturated fatty acids, lowered the iodine value, and significantly decreased carotenoid content. The treatment also resulted in minimal trans-fatty acid formation and maintained acceptable peroxide and free fatty acid levels.
population_specificity: Crude soybean oil (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 15 kV with 100% hydrogen gas for 13 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a blend oil (50% lard and 50% soybean oil) on cardiometabolic risk factors, comparing it to soybean oil and lard alone in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The blend oil significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to soybean oil and lard alone, particularly in participants with elevated blood pressure or higher BMI. No significant differences were observed in body weight, waist circumference, serum lipids, or glucose levels between the groups.
population_specificity: 334 healthy subjects (mean age 33.1 years, 60% women).
effective_dosage: 30 g/day of soybean oil, lard, or blend oil (50% lard and 50% soybean oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify immune-related proteins in fish liver tissue when fed a soybean oil-based diet compared to a fish oil-based diet, focusing on inflammatory and immune responses.
results_summary: The study found that a soybean oil-based diet upregulated NF-κB signaling-related proteins and activated the MAPK pathway, promoting immune cell migration. Linolenic acid (LNA) from soybean oil inhibited Nrf2 expression but increased NF-κB and MAPK pathway-related signaling proteins.
population_specificity: Fish (species not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ultrasound treatment on myofibrillar protein properties in the presence or absence of soybean oil.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment at 300 W reduced emulsion droplet size and increased zeta potential. It also increased protein oxidation and unfolded more protein molecules in the MP-soybean oil system compared to the oil-free system.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of a novel ultrasonic microreactor (USMR) for producing stable soybean oil-in-water nanoemulsions with optimal droplet size and polydispersity.
results_summary: The USMR demonstrated superior emulsification efficiency, producing nanoemulsions with uniform droplet size (96.4 nm) and low polydispersity (0.195), which exhibited excellent stability over 45 days at 4℃ and 25℃. The method outperformed traditional ultrasonic probes in terms of energy efficiency, throughput, and scalability.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of unmodified soybean oil (SO) and partially-hydrogenated soybean oil (PHSO) on plasma metabolite profiles and lipid-related pathways in hypercholesterolemic individuals.
results_summary: The study found that PHSO intake led to higher plasma levels of phospholipids and di-/triglycerides compared to SO, with glycerophospholipid biosynthesis being the most active pathway. Seven metabolites were identified as potential biomarkers for PHSO intake.
population_specificity: Moderately hypercholesterolemic individuals (N = 10, age 63 ± 8 y, BMI 26.2 ± 4.2 kg/m², LDL-C 3.9 ± 0.5 mmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary resveratrol supplementation on growth performance, antioxidant capacity, inflammatory state, and intestinal function in weaned piglets challenged with oxidized soybean oil.
results_summary: Oxidized soybean oil impaired growth, increased inflammation, and damaged intestinal barriers in piglets, while resveratrol supplementation improved antioxidant capacity, reduced inflammation, and enhanced intestinal health.
population_specificity: Weaned male piglets (castrated) with an initial body weight of 10.19 ± 0.10 kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rosemary extract (ROE) could enhance the oxidative stability of soybean oil used for frying breaded butterfly shrimp, compared to control oils without antioxidants.
results_summary: The study found that rosemary extract significantly delayed soybean oil oxidation, as evidenced by lower levels of oxidation markers (TPM, PI, FFA) and extended induction periods. ROE also reduced oil consumption by fried foods, improving oil stability and shelf life.
population_specificity: Soybean oil used for frying breaded butterfly shrimp (no human subjects specified).
study_duration: Not specified (evaluation focused on final hours of frying)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing beef cows with Ca salts of soybean oil (CSSO) via low-moisture blocks (LMB) during the breeding season improved reproductive and productive outcomes.
results_summary: Cows receiving CSSO had higher ω-6 fatty acid concentrations, improved pregnancy rates to fixed-time AI, reduced pregnancy loss, earlier calving, and greater weaning rates and calf weight per cow exposed compared to controls.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant, suckled multiparous Angus-influenced beef cows.
effective_dosage: 25% CSSO in LMB, targeting a daily intake of 0.454 kg/cow (as-fed basis).
study_duration: From day -10 to day 100 (110 days total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of peroxidized soybean oil (PSO) on pig performance, digestibility, intestinal morphology, and oxidative stress markers in nursery pigs.
results_summary: Feeding pigs diets containing PSO reduced apparent total tract digestibility of gross energy and nitrogen, plasma vitamin E concentration, and pig performance, but did not affect intestinal morphology or oxidative markers in the liver or ileum.
population_specificity: Nursery pigs (initial body weight 7.14 kg in EXP 1 and 10.6 kg in EXP 2).
effective_dosage: 7.5% soybean oil or PSO in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel enzymatic degumming process using lipase GMGL and phospholipase A1 to improve the quality of crude soybean oil by reducing phosphorus content and identifying differential phospholipids.
results_summary: The combined enzymatic treatment significantly reduced phosphorus content in crude soybean oil from 680.50 to 2.01 mg/kg, achieving a high oil yield of 98.80%. The study also identified 21 differential phospholipids between crude and enzymatically treated soybean oil using UPLC-Q-TOF-MS.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on crude soybean oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare catheter-related bloodstream infection (CR-BSI) rates in pediatric patients receiving parenteral nutrition with soybean oil-based intravenous fat emulsion (SO-IFE) versus mixed oil-IFE (MO-IFE).
results_summary: The study found that MO-IFE was associated with significantly lower rates of coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS) and total CR-BSIs compared to SO-IFE. Total infection rates were 7.33 per 1000 days for SO-IFE and 4.52 per 1000 days for MO-IFE.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (<18 years) with central venous catheters receiving parenteral nutrition.
effective_dosage: Not specified (at least three times weekly for ≥7 days).
study_duration: Retrospective data from January 2015 to July 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of oxidized soybean oil in sow diets on sow performance and jejunum health of suckling piglets.
results_summary: Oxidized soybean oil did not affect sow performance but reduced antioxidant enzyme activity in milk and increased inflammatory markers in both sow milk and piglet plasma. It also altered cytokine expression and tight junction protein levels in piglets.
population_specificity: Sows from 107 days gestation to 21 days of lactation and their suckling piglets.
study_duration: From 107 days gestation to 21 days of lactation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical benefits of switching from pure soybean oil-based lipid emulsion to a mixed lipid emulsion (4-OLE) in parenteral nutrition, focusing on patient outcomes such as length of stay, liver function, and infection rates.
results_summary: The study found that 4-OLE was associated with shorter hospital and ICU length of stay, reduced urinary tract infection rates, and mitigated hepatic dysfunction in critically ill patients, with no significant associations in AST, ALT, or total bilirubin levels in the broader adult cohort.
population_specificity: Adult patients (>18 years) requiring parenteral nutrition, including a subset of critically ill ICU patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sumac fruit extracts (SFE) in enhancing the oxidative stability of soybean oil compared to synthetic antioxidants under accelerated storage conditions.
results_summary: All sumac fruit extract treatments significantly prevented chemical and sensory degradation of soybean oil in a dose-dependent manner, with immersion-extracted SFE (I-SFE) showing the best performance in reducing oxidation markers (peroxide value, TBARS, acid value) and achieving the highest sensory scores. I-SFE at 999.998 ppm optimally extended soybean oil shelf life by 11.36 days under accelerated conditions, matching synthetic antioxidant efficacy.
population_specificity: Soybean oil under accelerated oxidative conditions (60°C storage)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary octanoate could repair intestinal damage induced by surplus soybean oil in Larimichthys crocea.
results_summary: Dietary octanoate improved intestinal physical barrier function, reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory response, and repaired microbial dysbiosis caused by surplus soybean oil. It also increased the relative abundance of beneficial bacteria like Lactobacillus and elevated acetic acid levels.
population_specificity: Larimichthys crocea (a species of fish)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of graded levels of high oleic soybean oil (HOSO) on pork loin and belly quality in growing-finishing pigs.
results_summary: HOSO diets increased visual marbling and redness in loin chops, improved belly dimensions, and altered fatty acid composition (higher oleic acid, lower palmitic and linoleic acid) without negatively affecting fresh loin quality or sensory traits.
population_specificity: Growing-finishing pigs (288 pigs in two blocks).
effective_dosage: 2%, 4%, and 6% high oleic soybean oil (HOSO2, HOSO4, HOSO6) in diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a bio-based drug delivery system using epoxidized soybean oil (ESO) and carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCS) for targeted antifungal treatment.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized CMCS-g-ESO conjugates, demonstrating sustained-release and pH-responsive properties. The microcapsules showed good antifungal efficacy against Fusarium oxysporum compared to unencapsulated spinosad.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
study_duration: Reaction time: 1 hour; release studies conducted under varying pH conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using Trichosporon fermentans for treating refined soybean oil wastewater (RSOW) and recovering microbial lipids through bioflocculation.
results_summary: The study found that optimal hydrodynamic parameters (turbulence kinetic energy, dissipation rate, and shear force) achieved a flocculation rate of over 90% for Trichosporon fermentans. An empirical formula was developed to predict flocculation performance, and a designed reactor achieved 91.3% flocculation efficiency.
population_specificity: Refined soybean oil wastewater (RSOW) treatment system

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of n-6 PUFA-rich soybean oil (SO) with MUFA-rich oils (olive oil and camellia seed oil) on body weight and cardiometabolic profiles in middle-aged and elderly Chinese women at high cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in body weight changes between the soybean oil group and the MUFA-rich oil groups. However, MUFA-rich oils showed more favorable effects on certain cardiometabolic markers (HDL cholesterol and AST) compared to soybean oil.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly Chinese women at high cardiovascular risk.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as cooking oil for lunch and dinner).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an optical method using LED-induced fluorescence spectroscopy to detect adulteration levels of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) with soybean oil.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that LED-induced fluorescence spectroscopy effectively predicted adulteration levels of EVOO with soybean oil, showing good linearity between predicted and actual concentrations. The method was non-destructive and required no pre-treatment, suggesting feasibility for real-market applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study on oil samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of graded levels of high oleic soybean oil (HOSO) on growth performance and carcass characteristics in growing-finishing pigs.
results_summary: Pigs fed higher levels of HOSO (4% and 6%) showed improved feed efficiency and reduced feed intake but had increased backfat thickness and reduced standardized fat-free lean. Minimal differences were observed in primal weights, which decreased with higher HOSO inclusion.
population_specificity: Growing-finishing pigs (288 pigs in two blocks).
effective_dosage: 2%, 4%, and 6% high oleic soybean oil (HOSO) in diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional and health-promoting fat indices in soybean seeds under varying nitrogen doses and inoculation with Bradyrhizobium japonicum.
results_summary: The study found that soybean oil's fat quality indices were strongly influenced by weather conditions, with cultivar Aldana showing higher Omega 6 and favorable MUFA/PUFA ratios, while Annushka had better consumer index (CI) and other favorable indices. Nitrogen dose and inoculation had no significant effect on most indices, but higher nitrogen rates without inoculation improved the dietary fatty acid balance.
population_specificity: Soybean cultivars grown in 2016-2019 under varying nitrogen doses and inoculation conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using terahertz spectroscopy combined with chemometric methods for rapid detection of capsaicin concentration in soybean oil as a marker for gutter oil.
results_summary: The study found that terahertz spectroscopy with chemometric methods (GA, PCA, LS-SVM, BPNN, PLS) effectively predicted capsaicin concentration in soybean oil, achieving high accuracy (100% in prediction set) and a detection limit of 1.25 µg/kg. The BPNN-GA combination provided the best quantitative prediction results.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on soybean oil samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Soybean Oil (SO), Fish Oil (FO), and Mixed Oil (MO) lipid emulsions on adipogenesis, lipogenesis, lipolysis, and β-oxidation in 3T3-L1 adipocytes.
results_summary: Soybean Oil (SO) showed higher triacylglycerol levels and increased mRNA expression of adipogenic and lipogenic genes compared to Fish Oil (FO) and Mixed Oil (MO), indicating less favorable effects on lipid metabolism. SO was less effective than FO and MO in reducing lipid accumulation and altering gene expression related to fat metabolism.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocytes (a mouse cell line used as a model for studying adipocyte biology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modifying soybean oil with acrylated epoxidized soybean oil (AESO) or a mixture of acrylic acid and soybean oil (AA/Soy), followed by nonthermal plasma (NTP) treatment, could improve dyeing performance on para-aramid textiles.
results_summary: The study found that AESO or AA/Soy pretreatments, combined with NTP, significantly enhanced dyeing color strength (K/S >9.00) compared to soybean oil alone (K/S 3.89), with covalent bonding facilitating dye adherence. AA/Soy was a cost-effective alternative to AESO, and NaCl improved dyeing, while Polysorbate 80 had a negative effect.
population_specificity: Para-aramid textiles (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (application method described but not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soybean oil and fish oil supplementation on fatigue in breast cancer survivors and assess whether nutritional status influenced serum omega-3 levels and fatigue outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that soybean oil supplementation did not significantly improve fatigue compared to fish oil, which showed greater increases in serum omega-3s and fatigue improvements in participants with good nutritional status.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors 4-36 months post-treatment with moderate-severe fatigue.
effective_dosage: 6 g soybean oil daily or 3 g soybean oil + 3 g fish oil daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the addition of NaCl affects the physical and oxidative stability of soybean oil body (SOB) emulsions under neutral (pH 7) and acidic (pH 3) conditions.
results_summary: NaCl reduced the physical and oxidative stability of SOB emulsions at pH 7, causing flocculation and increased lipid oxidation, but these effects were mitigated at pH 3. Acidic conditions and higher ionic strength improved emulsion stability against coalescence.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soybean oil supplementation to sows in the first three days after farrowing could improve piglet survival by enhancing the nutritional quality of sow milk.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of soybean oil supplementation on sow performance, reproduction, milk fat content, or piglet mortality and fall-back rate.
population_specificity: Sows and their newborn piglets.
effective_dosage: 604.5, 750, 1000, 1250, and 1500 g of soybean oil per sow over three days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the solubility of hydrogen in soybean oil and establish a method for controlling trans fatty acids (TFAs) during hydrogenation.
results_summary: The study found a linear relationship between hydrogen solubility in soybean oil and moles of hydrogen in the reactor. Under optimal conditions, hydrogenation stabilized above 3.0 MPa, providing a method to control TFAs in industrial applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oxidized soybean oil (OSO) on placental injury and fetal development in gestational rats.
results_summary: Oxidized soybean oil (OSO) decreased placental and embryonic weights, altered apoptosis-related gene expression (increased Bax, decreased Bcl-2), reduced Fosl1 and Esx1 expression, disrupted cytokine levels (decreased IL-10, increased IL-1β), and modulated nutrient transporters (upregulated Fatp1 and Glut1, downregulated Snat2 and Glut3). These changes led to impaired placental growth and reduced fetal weight.
population_specificity: Pregnant adult rats (32 female rats divided into four groups).
effective_dosage: Oxidized soybean oil (OSO) at 200, 400, and 800 mEqO2 kg-1 (replacing lipid content in diet).
study_duration: From conception until delivery (day 20 of gestation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of microbial consortia (Bacillus subtilis and Rhodotorula mucilaginosa) for biological treatment and low-cost reuse of spent soybean oil.
results_summary: The study found that the microbial consortium showed promise for oil degradation and waste treatment, with spent soybean oil serving as a carbon source. Despite low biomass productivity, the treated oil had favorable characteristics for potential use in animal feed supplementation.
population_specificity: Microbial strains (Rhodotorula mucilaginosa and Bacillus subtilis) in a laboratory setting.
effective_dosage: Medium containing 0.075% glucose and 0.375% (NH4)3PO4 in 75 mL water and 75 mL spent soy oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how quercetin inhibits aldehyde formation in thermally treated soybean oil and identify the resulting phenolic derivatives.
results_summary: Quercetin significantly reduced unsaturated aldehyde formation in soybean oil during heating, though its inhibitory effect weakened over time. New quercetin derivatives formed, some with weaker antioxidant activity but one (quercetin-3-O-hexanoate) showed improved cellular antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on soybean oil)
study_duration: Not specified (heat treatment duration not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different immobilized enzymes for one-step synthesis of biodiesel and recovery of bioactive compounds from soybean oil deodorizer distillate (SODD).
results_summary: Immobilized lipase MAS1-H108A achieved the highest biodiesel yield (97.08%) under optimized conditions, maintained activity over 10 cycles, and preserved tocopherols and squalene. Pure biodiesel and bioactive compounds were successfully separated via molecular distillation.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Molar ratio of 1:2 (oil/methanol), enzyme loading of 35 U/g SODD.
study_duration: Not specified (reaction conditions optimized, but duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with soybean oil (SBO) could enhance milk quality in dairy goats under heat stress and thermal neutral conditions.
results_summary: SBO supplementation increased milk fat by 29% and conjugated linoleic acid by 360% without affecting feed intake, milk yield, or milk protein content. These benefits were consistent regardless of heat stress conditions.
population_specificity: Multiparous Murciano-Granadina dairy goats in mid-lactation.
effective_dosage: 4% of soybean oil in the diet.
study_duration: 21 days per period (14 days adaptation, 5 days measurement, 2 days transition).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of blending sludge oil with soybean oil for biodiesel production through transesterification.
results_summary: The study found that blends of sludge oil and soybean oil, under optimal conditions (1:6 oil blend:methanol ratio, 0.5% NaOH, 70°C for 60 min), yielded biodiesel with over 99% efficiency and met physicochemical standards set by ANP.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of a soybean oil-based injectable lipid emulsion (SO-ILE) versus a 4-oil alternative (SMOFlipid) in preterm neonates, focusing on outcomes like cholestasis and hypertriglyceridemia.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the incidence of cholestasis or hypertriglyceridemia between SO-ILE and SMOFlipid groups (14.6% vs. 18.1%). There were also no significant differences in ursodiol treatment duration or body weight change between the groups.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates born at ≤34 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 500 to 2,000 g admitted to neonatal intensive care units (NICUs).
study_duration: At least 7 days of parenteral nutrition containing the lipid emulsion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of soybean oil in hydrophobizing starch for use as a biodegradable, water-resistant coating on paper.
results_summary: The study found that soybean oil-modified starch demonstrated high hydrophobicity, with a contact angle of 121° initially and 111° after 10 minutes, indicating strong water-resistant properties. The modified starch formed a textured surface with dual roughness levels, enhancing its hydrophobic performance.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study on materials, not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (used in the hydrophobization process, but exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (single treatment process described, no longitudinal follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of plant-based substances and synthetic antioxidants against the oxidation of antioxidant-free soybean oil using near-infrared spectroscopy and PARAFAC analysis.
results_summary: The study found that plant-based extracts were more effective in improving the frying stability of soybean oil compared to synthetic antioxidants. Oxidation product concentration increased while antioxidant concentration decreased with rising temperature.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on soybean oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether including Opuntia stricta cladodes in a soybean oil-supplemented diet would enhance the nutraceutical value of milk fat by promoting incomplete rumen biohydrogenation of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA).
results_summary: Soybean oil supplementation, particularly when combined with Opuntia stricta cladodes, increased beneficial fatty acids like trans-11 18:1 and cis-9, trans-11 CLA in milk fat while reducing 18:0 and cis-9 18:1. The partial mixed ration (CC-PMR) showed the most pronounced effects, improving milk yield and nutrient intake without altering gross milk composition.
population_specificity: Twelve Holstein cows

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bacterial cellulose from soybean oil refinery effluent as an immobilization carrier for oleaginous yeasts to treat the effluent and produce bio-oil.
results_summary: The study found that immobilization with bacterial cellulose achieved 50% immobilization of oleaginous yeasts, with 92.1% chemical oxygen demand removal and 93.1% oil content removal. The immobilized yeasts also facilitated bio-oil production with higher alkanes and calorific value compared to free yeasts.
population_specificity: Soybean oil refinery effluent (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 30% mass percentage of bacterial cellulose, 24-hour immobilization time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different preheat treatments on the composition, rheological properties, and physical stability of soybean oil bodies, as well as their application in coffee stability.
results_summary: UHT-treated samples showed the highest oil body and protein yields but lower oil content, while soymilk heated at 65-75°C had high oil body extraction yields. UHT samples exhibited larger particle size and higher viscosity, and the diluted emulsion remained stable for 15 days at 4°C. High oleosin and low storage protein content in oil bodies benefited coffee stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (processing conditions: 65-85°C for 30 min, UHT at 110-130°C for 10 s)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soybean oil and calcium salts of fatty acids (CSFAs) on nutrient digestion and cecal fermentation parameters in horses.
results_summary: Soybean oil and CSFAs had similar effects on nutrient digestibility (DM, NDF, ADF, CP, CF, GE). Soybean oil led to a temporary decrease in cecal pH and higher cecal VFA concentrations at hour 2 compared to CSFAs, but no significant differences in serum cholesterol were observed.
population_specificity: Eight cecally cannulated Quarter Horses
effective_dosage: 4.1% soybean oil in pelleted concentrate (0.5% body weight as-fed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of supplementing late-gestation cows with Ca salts of soybean oil (CSSO) versus prilled saturated fat (CON) on offspring growth, health, and physiological responses.
results_summary: CSSO supplementation increased plasma linoleic acid and ω-6 PUFA concentrations, improved immunoglobulin G levels in colostrum and calves, enhanced gene expression related to muscle and fat development, and reduced the incidence of bovine respiratory disease (BRD) in calves. Calves from CSSO-supplemented cows also showed greater feedyard growth and larger longissimus muscle area at slaughter.
population_specificity: Pregnant, nonlactating, multiparous Angus × Hereford cows and their offspring.
effective_dosage: 195 g/cow daily of CSSO (dry matter basis).
study_duration: From day 0 of the experiment (day 180 of gestation) until calving.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soybean oil or palmitic acid-enriched triglycerides influenced nutrient partitioning toward body tissues or milk synthesis in dairy cows.
results_summary: Soybean oil decreased milk fat content, fat-corrected milk yield, and energy-corrected milk yield but increased body weight gain and plasma insulin levels compared to palmitic acid-enriched triglycerides. It also reduced neutral detergent fiber digestibility but increased fatty acid digestibility.
population_specificity: Thirty-two Holstein cows (93 ± 35 days in milk).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a molasses-based supplement enriched with Ca salts of soybean oil (CSSO) delivered via self-fed blocks versus hand-fed granular concentrate on plasma fatty acid profiles in forage-fed beef cows.
results_summary: The study found that CSSO inclusion in self-fed blocks resulted in similar plasma concentrations of ω-6 polyunsaturated and total fatty acids compared to hand-fed concentrate, indicating comparable efficacy. Plasma levels of linoleic acid, ω-6 polyunsaturated FA, and total FA were higher in supplemented cows than unsupplemented ones, with transient differences between delivery methods.
population_specificity: Nonlactating, nonpregnant, multiparous beef cows.
effective_dosage: CSSO at 24.7% of dry matter in supplements; LMB intake averaged 0.570 kg/d (DM basis), CONC at 0.583 kg/d (DM basis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence and severity of intestinal failure-associated liver disease (IFALD) in neonates receiving soybean oil-based lipid emulsions (SOLEs) versus mixed oil-based lipid emulsions (MOLEs) during long-term parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in IFALD occurrence between SOLE and MOLE groups (44.8% vs. 30%), with lipid type not being a significant predictor after adjusting for confounders. Duration of PN and lipids were identified as significant risk factors for IFALD, regardless of emulsion type.
population_specificity: Neonates admitted to a neonatal intensive care nursery requiring parenteral nutrition for ≥14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ultrasonically treated arabinoxylans (AX) on their antioxidant capacity and ability to improve the oxidative stability of soybean oil.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment modified AX's molecular weight distribution, with AX-1 showing the highest antioxidant activity (75% inhibition at 533 µg/mL). AX and AX-1 at specific concentrations significantly improved soybean oil's oxidative stability, with induction periods of 7.69 and 5.54 hours, respectively.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mixed oil lipid emulsion (including soybean oil) versus other lipid emulsions on cholestasis and other disease states in very low birth weight neonates receiving parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in cholestasis incidence between groups but observed lower risks of non-stage-0 retinopathy of prematurity, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, sepsis, and necrotizing enterocolitis in the mixed oil lipid emulsion group.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight neonates (215 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soybean oil (SO) and Brazil nut oil (BNO) supplementation on anthropometric, blood pressure, biochemical, and oxidative parameters in patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Soybean oil supplementation increased total and LDL cholesterol but improved total antioxidant capacity. It did not affect anthropometric or blood pressure variables.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (n=16 in the SO group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of feeding soybean oil with varying levels of peroxidation on nutrient digestibility, gut integrity, oxidative stress, and growth performance in nursery pigs.
results_summary: Pigs fed soybean oil processed at 90°C showed reduced growth performance (ADG and ADFI) compared to other groups, but no significant effects were observed on nutrient digestibility, gut permeability, or most oxidative stress markers. However, increased isoprostane concentrations (a marker of oxidative stress) were noted in serum and urine for the 90°C processed group.
population_specificity: Nursery pigs (initial body weight 7.1 ± 0.9 kg and 9.16 ± 1.56 kg).
effective_dosage: Diets containing 10% soybean oil (varying processing conditions).
study_duration: 21 days (Experiment 1), duration for Experiment 2 not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oxidative stability and fatty acid composition of soybean oil (SO) when blended with rice bran oil (RBO) under extreme thermal conditions.
results_summary: Blending SO with RBO reduced oxidative degradation and slowed the deterioration of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) during heating. Pure SO showed the highest degradation, while blends with RBO exhibited improved oxidative stability, with protective effects increasing with RBO concentration.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on oil samples)
study_duration: Heating at frying temperature (170°C), duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether soybean oil, compared to other common oils, could protect against carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced liver fibrosis in mice.
results_summary: Soybean oil significantly reduced liver damage markers (ALT, AST, MDA, HYP, TG) and showed less fibrosis and apoptosis compared to corn or lard oil, similar to olive oil.
population_specificity: Healthy male ICR mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pre-treatment with oils, CCl4 administered at 2.5 ml/kg twice weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a swirling demulsified airlift loop reactor (SD-ALR) in treating refined soybean oil wastewater compared to a traditional airlift loop reactor.
results_summary: The SD-ALR reduced wastewater treatment time by 8 hours and improved chemical oxygen demand and oil content removal by 5.10% and 9.55%, respectively, compared to the traditional reactor. A volumetric mass transfer coefficient model was also established for the SD-ALR and oily wastewater.
population_specificity: Refined soybean oil wastewater (industrial application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of supplementing Ca salts of soybean oil (CSSO) on beef steer performance, carcass development, and gene expression related to adipogenesis.
results_summary: CSSO supplementation increased plasma concentrations of linoleic acid, ω-6, and total fatty acids, and upregulated mRNA expression of adipogenic genes, but did not improve performance or carcass quality traits like marbling or backfat thickness.
population_specificity: Beef steers (64 total, 32 per year) at 2 months of age.
effective_dosage: 80 g/d per steer during creep-feeding (CF) and 150 g/d per steer during preconditioning (PC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bifunctionalized nanoliposomes containing Persian clover sprout extract in delaying the oxidation process of soybean oil.
results_summary: The study found that nanoliposomal forms of the methanolic extract significantly delayed soybean oil oxidation, with stable nanoliposomal structures demonstrating strong antioxidant activity. The most effective formulation contained 30% oil, 5% lecithin, and 2% extract.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on soybean oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether solid waste sludge from soybean oil plants could be used as a catalyst carrier for denitration, focusing on optimizing activation and calcination conditions.
results_summary: The study found that sludge activated with 15% LiOH for 4 hours and calcined at 450°C for 4 hours showed the best denitration efficiency, with confirmed structural and functional improvements via FTIR, XPS, XRD, and SEM analysis.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Not applicable (experimental conditions: 4 hours activation, 4 hours calcination).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether refined cottonseed oil (CSO) could effectively replace soybean oil (SBO) in broiler diets without adverse effects on performance, liver function, or muscle fatty acid composition.
results_summary: Substituting up to 50% SBO with CSO improved broiler growth and feed efficiency without negative effects, while higher CSO levels (75-100%) altered serum protein, cholesterol, and muscle fatty acid profiles. CSO also appeared to enhance antioxidant status.
population_specificity: 180 one-day-old broiler chickens.
effective_dosage: Replacement levels of 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% (w/w) of SBO with CSO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using terahertz spectroscopy combined with chemometrics for rapid detection of aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) contamination in soybean oil.
results_summary: The study found that terahertz spectroscopy combined with back propagation neural network (BPNN) and t-SNE provided excellent prediction results for AFB1 in soybean oil, with high accuracy (over 90%) at detecting AFB1 levels as low as 1 µg/kg. The method demonstrated strong correlation (Rp = 0.9948) and low error (RMSEP = 0.7124 µg/kg).
population_specificity: Soybean oil samples contaminated with AFB1.
effective_dosage: Not specified (detection method focused on AFB1 levels, not dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (methodological study, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acrylated epoxidized soybean oil (AESO)-based coatings could reduce moisture sensitivity and permeability in starch-based materials.
results_summary: The study found that AESO coatings significantly reduced moisture sensitivity and permeability (by more than 10 times) in starch-based films, with crosslinking density being a key factor for water resistance.
population_specificity: Starch-based films (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (AESO concentration varied but exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (UV crosslinking was immediate but overall study duration unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of using oleaginous yeast Trichosporon fermentans and flocculants produced by Paecilomyces sp. M2-1 to treat soybean oil refinery wastewater and produce microbial oil.
results_summary: The study found that MBF2-1 flocculants effectively harvested T. fermentans, achieving a 95% flocculation percentage, and further removed 55% of COD and 53% of oil content in the wastewater without significantly affecting fatty acid content in microbial oil.
population_specificity: Soybean oil refinery wastewater and oleaginous yeast T. fermentans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of mixed-oil (MO) intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) as an alternative to soybean oil (SO) ILE in home parenteral nutrition (HPN) patients with SO ILE intolerance.
results_summary: The study found that MO ILE was well tolerated, improved macronutrient composition, and enhanced some liver parameters over 12 months compared to SO ILE. Patients showed stability in alkaline phosphatase and triglyceride levels, with improvements in aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, total bilirubin, and α-tocopherol levels.
population_specificity: 17 HPN patients (8 female, 9 male) with chronic intestinal failure and SO ILE intolerance, average age 47 ± 12 years, median HPN duration 4.6 years.
effective_dosage: SO ILE dose maintained at <1 g/kg/day before transition to MO ILE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary inclusion of soybean oil, alone or combined with monensin or coconut oil, influenced ruminal methane emission and nutrient digestibility in Alpine doelings.
results_summary: Soybean oil inclusion (3% or 1.5%) reduced ruminal methane emission compared to the control, but its effect was not markedly different from other treatments. Nitrogen digestibility was lower in soybean oil-containing diets compared to the control.
population_specificity: Alpine doelings (initial BW 31.7 ± 0.38 kg, age 306 ± 1.9 d)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term outcomes of children with IF-associated liver disease (IFALD) who were treated with fish oil (FO) and then resumed soybean oil (SO).
results_summary: FO effectively treated cholestasis, but resuming SO was associated with cholestasis redevelopment in nearly one-fourth of subjects. Long-term FO may be necessary to prevent end-stage liver disease.
population_specificity: Children with intestinal failure (IF) and IF-associated liver disease (IFALD).
study_duration: 6 months of FO, followed by SO resumption and follow-up for a median of 16 months.
