study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the denitration efficiency of catalysts using dried soybean oil sludge as a carrier, focusing on activation conditions and sequences.
results_summary: The study found that a LiOH concentration of 15% and activation time of four hours yielded the best denitration effect, with pre-plasma roasting activation showing superior catalytic activity.
population_specificity: Soybean oil plant wastewater treatment sludge (C/N ratio of 9.64).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the oleaginous yeast *Trichosporon fermentans* could effectively treat refined soybean oil wastewater (RSOW) by converting it into microbial lipids for potential biodiesel production.
results_summary: The study found that *Trichosporon fermentans* effectively removed 94.7% of COD and 89.9% of oil content from RSOW, producing 3.4 g/L of microbial lipids with 43% lipid content, suitable for biodiesel. Optimal conditions were identified (28.3°C, 5.9% inoculum, pH 6.1) for efficient treatment and lipid production.
population_specificity: Refined soybean oil wastewater (RSOW) treated by *Trichosporon fermentans*.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the organoleptic properties of frankfurter-type sausages when pork backfat was replaced with soybean oil or rice bran wax oleogels.
results_summary: Soybean oil (SBO) was used as a lipid replacement in frankfurters, showing no significant differences in firmness, chewiness, or springiness compared to pork fat. However, cured frankfurter flavor was significantly reduced when pork fat was replaced.
population_specificity: Frankfurters (food product study, no human subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as a lipid replacement in formulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of feeding soybean oil with varying levels of peroxidation on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and gut integrity in finishing pigs.
results_summary: Pigs fed soybean oil processed at higher temperatures (90°C and 180°C) showed reduced growth performance, energy and lipid digestibility, and lower plasma tryptophan levels, but no significant effects on nitrogen digestibility or gut permeability.
population_specificity: Finishing pigs (56 barrows, initial body weight 46.7 ± 5.1 kg).
effective_dosage: 10% soybean oil in the diet, with varying processing conditions (22.5°C, 45°C for 288 h, 90°C for 72 h, or 180°C for 6 h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of soybean oil as a fat source in cow diets on ruminal kinetics, fermentation, fatty acid abomasal flow, and milk fatty acid profile.
results_summary: Soybean oil supplementation increased fatty acid abomasal flow, particularly C18:0 and total fatty acids, but had minimal effects on ruminal digestibility and milk fat concentration compared to the control. It tended to decrease ruminal neutral detergent fiber digestibility.
population_specificity: Eight Holstein cows in early- to mid-lactation (80 ± 20 days in milk, 22.9 ± 0.69 kg/d milk yield, 580 ± 20 kg body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing calcium salts of soybean oil (CSSO) during early gestation improves reproductive function and pregnancy rates in beef cows.
results_summary: CSSO supplementation increased pregnancy rates (60.2% vs. 51.7%) and enhanced mRNA expression of interferon-tau and other genes linked to pregnancy, suggesting improved reproductive outcomes. Plasma concentrations of linoleic acid and ω-6 FA were also higher in CSSO-treated cows.
population_specificity: Multiparous Angus and Angus × Hereford beef cows in early gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary soybean oil, fish oil, and coconut oil on the performance, egg quality, and blood parameters of laying hens.
results_summary: Soybean oil performed comparably to coconut oil in terms of hen performance and egg quality, with no significant adverse effects reported. Fish oil, however, negatively impacted egg weight and increased blood malondialdehyde (MDA), aspartate transaminase (AST), and uric acid (UA) levels.
population_specificity: 28-week-old Hy-line laying hens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of soybean oil (as a placebo) and dietary interventions on HDL and LDL-cholesterol subfractions in patients with psoriatic arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that soybean oil (used as a placebo) did not alter LDL subfractions, but the nutritional intervention (including omega-3 supplementation) improved HDL subfractions. No significant adverse effects or benefits specific to soybean oil were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriatic arthritis (n=91).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chronic consumption of interesterified fat (IF) compared to soybean oil (SO) on locomotor impairments and brain molecular targets in rats during early life and adulthood.
results_summary: Pups from the IF group showed impaired motor skill learning and sensorimotor behavior, while adult offspring exhibited decreased locomotion and reduced dopaminergic targets and GDNF in the striatum. Soybean oil was used as a comparison but its specific effects were not highlighted as negatively as IF.
population_specificity: Female rats during pregnancy and lactation, and their male offspring from weaning to adulthood.
study_duration: From pregnancy through lactation for mothers, and from weaning until adulthood for offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soybean oil, used as a placebo, had any effects on mood, impulsivity, or brain functionality in healthy adults with low omega-3 intake.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the soybean oil placebo group and the omega-3 supplementation group in measures of mood, impulsivity, or brain functionality, indicating soybean oil had no detectable effects in these areas.
population_specificity: Healthy adults with low intake of omega-3 fatty acids (≤300 mg/d of EPA and DHA).
effective_dosage: Identical-appearing soybean oil capsules (exact dosage not specified, used as placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate food and nutrient intakes in children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) adhering to the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) and compare these to general population recommendations and intakes.
results_summary: Children on the SCD met recommended fruit and vegetable intake and had higher dietary fiber intake compared to the general population, but showed inadequate calcium intake and elevated saturated fatty acid and red meat consumption. The SCD group had a lower likelihood of overall nutrient inadequacy but raised concerns regarding known JIA comorbidities.
population_specificity: Ten children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects and long-term impact of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) on medication needs in children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).
results_summary: The SCD showed short-term symptom improvement in some participants, with six avoiding medication escalations for a year, but no significant group-level changes in medication use were observed. Long-term adherence was challenging, and larger studies with simpler diets are needed.
population_specificity: Children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and low disease activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of stearoyl-CoA desaturase 1 (SCD1) in stabilizing MafA expression and activity to maintain functional beta cell mass and suppress type 2 diabetes development.
results_summary: SCD1 expression was reduced in diabetic beta cells, and its gain-of-function improved insulin deficiency, glucose intolerance, and beta cell function in mouse models. SCD1 stabilized MafA by inhibiting its ubiquitination-mediated degradation and alleviated glucotoxicity-induced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Humans with type 2 diabetes, hyperglycemic db/db mice, and high-fat diet-induced diabetic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review nutritional interventions, including the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD), for their effectiveness in managing periodontitis and inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD).
results_summary: The study identified SCD as one of the recommended diets for IBD patients, alongside other dietary protocols, but did not provide specific efficacy data or comparative outcomes for SCD alone.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) and periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary interventions, including the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD), in managing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that strict diets like SCD demonstrated excellent outcomes in patients with IBD, comparable to other dietary interventions such as the Mediterranean diet. However, the specific components of the diet contributing to these benefits remain unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD).

study_goal: To explore children's and parents' experiences with the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) as a dietary intervention for juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and identify challenges and support needs.
results_summary: Most participants reported positive effects, including reduced pain, morning stiffness, and improved gastrointestinal function, with 12 out of 13 families willing to repeat the intervention. Challenges included socio-emotional difficulties for children and practical issues for parents, but overall experiences were favorable.
population_specificity: Children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and their parents.
study_duration: Four-week intervention, with some children continuing for one to three months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) could induce and maintain deep remission (clinical, endoscopic, radiographic, and histologic) in a patient with Crohn's disease.
results_summary: The study found that SCD monotherapy successfully induced and maintained deep mucosal remission in a patient with perianal and ileocolonic Crohn's disease, demonstrating effectiveness across multiple measures of disease activity.
population_specificity: A single patient with perianal and ileocolonic Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess barriers to initiating or maintaining the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in pediatric IBD patients to improve access and adherence.
results_summary: Parents chose SCD due to medication safety concerns, with major barriers being cost, time commitment, and psychosocial impact. Some parents reported improved personal health and nutrition understanding, and all advocated for more dietary therapy research.
population_specificity: Parents of 10 children with IBD receiving care at a single academic treatment center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of dietary interventions, including the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD), in managing Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), focusing on Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis.
results_summary: The study found that nutritional interventions, including SCD, can improve clinical symptoms and reduce inflammatory burden in IBD patients, though more research is needed on long-term dietary options and mechanisms.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of soybean oil (Intralipid) and predominantly olive oil (Clinoleic) lipid emulsions on serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and other outcomes in patients receiving parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in ALP or other liver function tests between the soybean oil and olive oil groups. However, the Clinoleic group had higher triglyceride levels and infection rates, while mortality and hospital stay were similar.
population_specificity: Adult surgical and medical patients receiving lipid emulsions for at least seven consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in symptom control and anti-inflammatory response in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The studies confirmed SCD's efficacy in symptom control but failed to demonstrate a sustained anti-inflammatory response. They highlighted the need for future studies to incorporate endoscopic endpoints and multi-omics analysis to better understand the diet's mechanism of action.
population_specificity: Patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of enteral nutrition (EN) use in children with IBD, including the effectiveness of new EN diets like the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD).
results_summary: The study found that SCD is one of the new EN diets being used for IBD, but it did not provide specific efficacy data for SCD compared to other EN methods. The abstract highlights that EEN (which includes SCD) has a strong effect on mild to moderate Crohn's disease.
population_specificity: Children with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
study_duration: Not specified for SCD specifically (general EEN treatment duration was 6-8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if improved clinical symptoms in children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) after SCD treatment were linked to changes in faecal microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that SCD impacted faecal microbiota composition, notably decreasing the relative abundance of Bifidobacterium and significantly reducing α-diversity. Despite small cohorts, SCD showed measurable effects on microbiota.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-17 years with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the latest evidence on the use of Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) for treating symptoms, active disease, and maintaining remission in ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that SCD is among the studied diets gaining popularity for IBD treatment, though there is growing interest in less restrictive diets like the Mediterranean diet. It suggests that healthful dietary patterns emphasizing whole foods and high vegetable fiber may also help achieve remission.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) and a modified SCD (MSCD) on symptoms and inflammation in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: SCD and MSCD performed similarly for most individuals, with no clinically meaningful difference in IBD symptoms or fecal calprotectin levels. Some individuals showed improvement compared to their usual diet, while others did not.
population_specificity: Patients aged 7-18 years with IBD and active inflammation.
study_duration: 8-week alternating periods (total intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and economic benefits of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in an adult male with complicated Crohn's disease non-responsive to medical management.
results_summary: The patient maintained the SCD for 42 months, achieving asymptomatic status, normalized fecal calprotectin levels, and resolution of inflammation on endoscopy and MRE. Healthcare costs decreased by 94% for insurance and 91% for out-of-pocket expenses.
population_specificity: Adult male with complicated Crohn's disease non-responsive to medical management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare nutrient intake differences between home-prepared and chef-prepared Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in children and adolescents with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The homemade SCD group had higher energy and protein intake, while the chef-prepared group showed higher intake of certain vitamins and minerals. Nutrient intake varied significantly between preparation methods, potentially influencing dietary therapy efficacy.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with active IBD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in treating and preventing relapses of inflammatory bowel diseases in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that SCD showed positive changes in anthropometric and inflammatory profiles, but results were inconclusive regarding its efficacy in treatment and relapse prevention.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with inflammatory bowel diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) versus the Mediterranean diet (MD) in achieving symptomatic remission and biomarker responses in adults with mild-to-moderate Crohn's disease.
results_summary: The SCD did not show superiority over the MD in achieving symptomatic remission, fecal calprotectin response, or CRP response at week 6. CRP response was rare in both groups.
population_specificity: Adult patients with Crohn's disease and mild-to-moderate symptoms.
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants received prepared meals and snacks for the first 6 weeks, then followed the diet independently).
study_duration: 12 weeks (6 weeks with prepared meals, 6 weeks independent adherence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential efficacy of three versions of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in achieving clinical remission and reducing inflammation in pediatric patients with mild to moderate Crohn's Disease.
results_summary: All participants who completed the study achieved clinical remission by week 12, with reductions in C-reactive protein levels across all diet groups. Microbiome composition shifted in all patients, with consistent metabolic changes observed, though the specific changes varied by individual.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (ages 7-18) with mild to moderate Crohn's Disease (PCDAI 15-45).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) monotherapy in achieving clinical, biochemical, and mucosal remission in pediatric Crohn's Disease (CD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that SCD monotherapy led to clinical and biochemical remission in pediatric CD patients but did not achieve complete mucosal healing after at least one year of follow-up. The results suggest SCD may sustain durable remission but lacks full mucosal healing efficacy.
population_specificity: Pediatric male patients with Crohn's Disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) as a dietary intervention to control inflammation in patients with Crohn's disease (CD) by excluding certain food components.
results_summary: The study found that SCD, along with other dietary interventions like CDED and CD-TREAT, showed promising results in controlling intestinal inflammation and inducing mucosal healing in CD patients, likely by impacting microbiota composition and excluding harmful food ingredients.
population_specificity: Patients with Crohn's disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) versus a modified SCD in treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) through personalized N-of-1 trials.
results_summary: The study design allows for personalized evaluation of SCD and modified SCD effectiveness, focusing on patient-reported outcomes and inflammation markers, but results are not yet aggregated or reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children and adults with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) to improve biochemical markers of inflammation and induce mucosal healing in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients.
results_summary: Recent uncontrolled clinical studies suggest that SCD may improve biochemical markers of inflammation and induce mucosal healing, but larger controlled studies are needed to confirm its efficacy due to its restrictive nature.
population_specificity: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients, including Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of carbohydrate variation in diet-based causation theories and treatments for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD).
results_summary: The study highlights that carbohydrate monotony or persistence is a shared characteristic of diet-based IBD therapies, including SCD, and suggests that further research on carbohydrate variation could advance prevention and treatment. It notes growing evidence for the success of SCD in both pediatric and adult IBD patients.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult patients with inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) on gastrointestinal symptoms, nutrient status, and behavioral concerns in a child with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and Fragile X Syndrome (FXS).
results_summary: The study reported improvements in nutrient status, gastrointestinal symptoms, and behavioral domains after 4 months of SCD intervention. The diet was well tolerated, suggesting potential benefits for children with ASD/FXS and GI issues.
population_specificity: A 4-year-old boy diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and Fragile X Syndrome (FXS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary interventions, including the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD), in modulating gut inflammation and improving symptoms of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that the SCD, along with other dietary interventions, has strong anti-inflammatory properties and shows promise for improving IBD symptoms, though more research is needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of insulin receptor isoforms (IRA and IRB) in improving glucose and lipid metabolism in a mouse model of high-fat-diet-induced obesity.
results_summary: The study found that hepatic expression of IRA, but not IRB, improved glucose uptake, insulin tolerance, and reduced hepatic steatosis by modulating key metabolic genes. The results suggest IRA as a potential therapeutic target for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease associated with obesity.
population_specificity: Mice with diet-induced insulin resistance and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate fecal microbiome changes and symptom control in a patient with ulcerative colitis (UC) and primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) following the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD).
results_summary: The SCD led to substantial fecal microbiome changes within two weeks, including increased Enterobacteriaceae and decreased Fusobacterium ulcerans, while UC symptoms were controlled within one week. Bacterial diversity and evenness improved near healthy control levels, though species richness remained low.
population_specificity: A 20-year-old female with UC and PSC, previously treated with high-dose oral vancomycin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional adequacy of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in pediatric patients with inflammatory bowel disease.
results_summary: Most participants met or exceeded recommended intakes for several vitamins, but deficiencies were noted in vitamin D and calcium. Weight gain was observed in most patients, but vitamin A intake exceeded upper limits.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with inflammatory bowel disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mucosal healing effects of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) and modified SCD (mSCD) in pediatric Crohn disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that while all subjects reported no active symptoms and had mostly normal lab results, complete mucosal healing was rare, with only one patient showing ileocolonic healing and none achieving full gastrointestinal tract healing.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients younger than 18 years with Crohn disease.

study_goal: To determine the effect of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) on active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that SCD was associated with significant clinical and laboratory improvements, including reductions in disease activity indices and C-reactive protein levels, as well as changes in fecal microbiome composition. However, the diet was ineffective for two patients, and two others could not maintain it.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (ages 10-17 years) with mild to moderate IBD (PCDAI 10-45 or PUCAI 10-65).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate IBD patients' perspectives on the usage and perceived efficacy of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD).
results_summary: The study found that many IBD patients perceived clinical improvement on the SCD, with remission rates increasing from 4% before the diet to 33% at 2 months and 42% at 6 and 12 months. Additionally, 47% of those who achieved remission reported improved abnormal laboratory values.
population_specificity: IBD patients (47% Crohn's disease, 43% ulcerative colitis, 10% indeterminate colitis), mean age 34.9 years, 70% female.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effects of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) on clinical outcomes and laboratory studies in pediatric patients with Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: The study found that SCD improved clinical outcomes, with significant reductions in disease activity indices for both CD and UC patients over time. However, the results were more consistent for CD than UC, and the study noted the need for further prospective research.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Crohn's disease (n=20) and ulcerative colitis (n=6).

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) as nutritional therapy for maintaining remission in pediatric Crohn's disease (CD).
results_summary: The study found that hematocrit, albumin, and ESR values improved while on strict SCD, with stable results after liberalization. Most children gained weight and height percentile during strict SCD, though small losses occurred with liberalization.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Crohn's disease (11 participants, aged 6.6-17.6 years).

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the hypoglycemic and hypolipidemic effects of neohesperidin (NHP) derived from Citrus aurantium L. in diabetic mice.
results_summary: NHP significantly reduced fasting glucose, serum glucose, and glycosylated serum protein, improved glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity, and lowered triglycerides, cholesterol, and liver lipid accumulation in diabetic mice. It also modulated gene expression related to lipid metabolism and activated the AMPK pathway.
population_specificity: KK-A(y) mice (diabetic model) and C57BL/6 mice (normal control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate clinical and mucosal responses to the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in children with Crohn's disease (CD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in clinical indices (HBI, PCDAI) and mucosal healing (LS) after 12 and 52 weeks of SCD, with sustained benefits in most patients. Two patients showed sustained mucosal healing at 52 weeks.
population_specificity: Children with active Crohn's disease (Pediatric Crohn's Disease Activity Index ≥ 15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in achieving symptomatic and clinical improvement, as well as complete remission, in an adult female with ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: The study found that after initiating the SCD, the patient showed improvement within 3-6 months, with complete resolution of symptoms and pancolitis within a year, and sustained remission at the 2-year follow-up. The diet led to a return to baseline functioning and career.
population_specificity: A 73-year-old Asian female with severe ulcerative colitis unresponsive to conventional therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) in pediatric patients with Crohn disease, focusing on symptom resolution and laboratory improvements.
results_summary: All seven children showed resolution of symptoms by 3 months after starting SCD, with significant improvements in laboratory indices such as serum albumin, C-reactive protein, hematocrit, and stool calprotectin. The study suggests SCD may be a viable dietary therapy for pediatric Crohn disease, though further prospective studies are needed.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Crohn disease (n=7) not receiving immunosuppressive medications.

study_goal: The study aimed to determine whether perinatal deltamethrin exposure altered the expression of adipogenic and lipogenic genes in white adipose tissue in adult offspring.
results_summary: Perinatal deltamethrin exposure decreased mRNA expression of adipogenesis-related transcription factors and lipogenic genes, as well as cytokine expression, without overtly affecting body or adipose weight. The findings suggest potential disruption of normal adipogenesis and lipid/glucose metabolism under dietary or environmental challenges.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 pregnant mice and their male offspring
study_duration: Throughout gestation and lactation (until postnatal day 25)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-carbohydrate (HC) and higher-fat (HF) diets on de novo lipogenesis (DNL) and stearoyl-CoA desaturase (SCD) activity in liver and adipose tissue.
results_summary: The study found that a short-term HC diet increased hepatic DNL and SCD activity, leading to higher plasma VLDL-TG concentrations and altered fatty acid ratios, while adipose tissue gene expression remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Eight subjects in a crossover study.
effective_dosage: HC diet (10% fat, 75% carbohydrates) and HF diet (40% fat, 45% carbohydrates) for 3 days each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of speleotherapy combined with pulmonary rehabilitation, endurance, and strength training on dynamic balance and chest mobility in older adults with chronic respiratory diseases.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in dynamic balance (measured by FSST) and chest mobility after a 3-week speleotherapy intervention, with average FSST time decreasing and chest expansion increasing.
population_specificity: Older adults (51 participants) with chronic respiratory disorders.

study_goal: The abstract does not address the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD); it focuses on changes in diabetes mellitus classification and diagnosis.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss the Specific Carbohydrate Diet (SCD) or its effects.
population_specificity: Not applicable (abstract does not study SCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) activity is required for the development of diet-induced hepatic insulin resistance.
results_summary: The study found that lowering hepatic Scd1 expression reversed diet-induced hepatic insulin resistance, significantly reducing glucose production, gluconeogenesis, and glycogenolysis while increasing Akt phosphorylation and decreasing expression of glucose-6-phosphatase and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.
population_specificity: Rats and mice with diet-induced insulin resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regulation of SCD isoforms, particularly the newly identified SCD4, in response to leptin and dietary factors, focusing on heart-specific expression.
results_summary: The study identified a novel heart-specific SCD isoform (SCD4) and found its expression was induced by LXR alpha agonists and a high carbohydrate fat-free diet but not repressed by dietary polyunsaturated fatty acids. Leptin deficiency increased SCD4 mRNA levels in the heart, which were reduced by leptin treatment.
population_specificity: Leptin-deficient ob/ob mice and wild-type controls

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of speleotherapy on bronchial reactivity to salbutamol in children with varying severity of bronchial asthma.
results_summary: Speleotherapy reduced bronchial tone and improved patency in children with intermittent asthma and partially improved bronchial hyperreactivity in mild asthma cases. The treatment showed positive effects on bronchial response to salbutamol.
population_specificity: 40 children aged 6-15 years with intermittent or mild bronchial asthma in the inter-relapse period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the presence of nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) and particulate matter (PM) in cave environments used for speleotherapy, evaluating potential safety concerns.
results_summary: NTM were isolated from spider webs in karst areas but not from PM in the speleotherapy cave, though mycobacterial DNA was detected. Air quality in the cave showed stable temperature and humidity, with low PM levels, but anions from nearby residential heating were noted.
population_specificity: Cave environments in four European countries (Czech Republic, France, Italy, Slovakia), including a speleotherapy facility in the Czech Republic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic and prophylactic effects of cryomassage and silvinite speleotherapy in patients with partially controlled asthma.
results_summary: The study found that combined cryomassage and speleotherapy had anti-inflammatory and immunocorrective effects, reduced bronchial obstruction and hyper-reactivity, improved pulmonary cardiohemodynamics, and enhanced physical tolerance and psychological adaptation.
population_specificity: Patients with partially controlled asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of pulmonary rehabilitation conducted in therapeutic salt mine chambers on the functional fitness of older adults with chronic respiratory conditions.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in five of six functional fitness parameters, including increased repetitions in Arm Curl and Chair Stand, improved flexibility in Sit and Reach, reduced time in 8-Foot Up and Go, and increased repetitions in 2-Minute Step. Beneficial but non-significant changes were observed in Back Scratch.
population_specificity: Older adults (>65 years) with chronic respiratory conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence for the efficacy of speleotherapy in the treatment of asthma.
results_summary: Two trials reported short-term benefits on lung function, but only one had reasonable methodological quality. The evidence was insufficient to reliably conclude speleotherapy's effectiveness for chronic asthma.
population_specificity: Asthmatic children (total of 124 participants across three trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence for the efficacy of speleotherapy in the treatment of chronic asthma.
results_summary: Two trials reported short-term benefits of speleotherapy on lung function in asthmatic children, but methodological quality was limited, and other outcomes could not be reliably assessed. The overall evidence was insufficient to draw definitive conclusions about its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Asthmatic children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether speleotherapy could reduce microbial contamination in the upper respiratory tract and inhibit staphylococcal persistence in children with respiratory allergosis.
results_summary: The study found that speleotherapy decreased microbial contamination in the upper respiratory tract and inhibited the persistence properties of staphylococcal microflora in children with respiratory allergosis, suggesting a positive therapeutic effect.
population_specificity: Children with respiratory allergosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of immunocorrective speleotherapy in treating atopic dermatitis in children.
results_summary: Positive trends were observed in dermatological status and immune homeostasis, with a complete response in 58% of patients, partial response in 20%, and no response in 6.9%. The method was recommended for treating atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: 112 children with atopic dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of speleotherapy on endocrine hormone levels and whether these changes correlated with radon exposure.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in cortisol levels, but no direct correlation with radon concentration. Thyroid hormone levels showed no significant changes except for a decrease in free thyroxine and thyreoiedea stimulating hormone in male patients at low radon concentrations.
population_specificity: 81 speleotherapy patients.
effective_dosage: Four hours daily in Tapolca Cave, five days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical, immunological, and functional effects of speleotherapy in children with bronchial asthma.
results_summary: Speleotherapy significantly reduced broncho-obstructive syndrome and improved pulmonary ventilation, with stable improvement observed in most patients, particularly those with mild or moderate atopic asthma.
population_specificity: 216 children with bronchial asthma treated in salt mines near Nakhichevan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of speleotherapy on selected immunological parameters, specifically CIK, Complement, Ig, and LSZ.
results_summary: The study found that speleotherapy affected CIK and Complement parameters, while Ig and LSZ parameters showed no systematic changes.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spermidine supplementation could alleviate symptoms of depression by addressing polyamine dysregulation and stimulating autophagy.
results_summary: Spermidine supplementation increased autophagy and reduced depressive symptoms in drug-naive depressed individuals, with similar effects observed in mouse models. The study also found that conventional antidepressants increased spermidine levels only in treatment responders.
population_specificity: Drug-naive depressed individuals (human trial) and various mouse stress and depression models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spermidine priming could alleviate drought stress effects on rice seedlings by improving root architecture, physiological responses, and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Spermidine priming significantly improved root and shoot growth, reduced oxidative damage, enhanced antioxidant activity, and upregulated auxin synthesis genes under drought stress, though its effects differed slightly from ascorbic acid priming.
population_specificity: Rice variety Hanyou 73 seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Speleotherapy on chronic obstructive airway diseases based on clinical experiences over a 10-year period.
results_summary: The study found significant and long-lasting clinical improvement and recovery from airway obstruction in the majority of patients, suggesting Speleotherapy as an effective environment for respiratory rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Over 4000 patients with chronic obstructive airway diseases treated in a hospital-cave complex in Tapolca, Hungary.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of speleotherapy on external respiration in asthma patients, including whether additional verapamil hydrochloride aerosol therapy enhanced these effects.
results_summary: Speleotherapy improved external respiration function in asthma patients, and verapamil hydrochloride further enhanced these beneficial effects.
population_specificity: 40 asthma patients (20 in each randomized group).
effective_dosage: Verapamil hydrochloride aerosol therapy (10 mg/day on days 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20, 22).
study_duration: 24-day course with 160 hours of total exposure.
interactions: Verapamil hydrochloride was noted to potentiate speleotherapy's effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how NAT1/NAT2 deficiency affects spermidine levels and its role in RIPK1-mediated cell death and diabetic phenotypes, as well as spermidine's potential therapeutic effects in type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Spermidine supplementation reduced RIPK1-mediated cell death and diabetic phenotypes in NAT1-deficient mice. Inhibition of RIPK1 also blocked insulin resistance and diabetic kidney disease in these mice, and decreased spermidine levels were observed in diabetic human vascular tissues.
population_specificity: NAT1-deficient mice and human patients with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a topical gel containing a spermidine-hyaluronate complex (UBIGEL donna™) in alleviating symptoms of vestibulodynia (VBD), either as a stand-alone or companion treatment.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, dyspareunia, vestibular trophism, muscle hypertonicity, and swab test results, with pain and dyspareunia scores decreasing by 46.5% and 33.5%, respectively. These improvements were consistent across various stratifications, including age and disease duration.
population_specificity: Women with vestibulodynia (n = 154).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether spermidine (SPD) could improve redox status and membrane impairments in erythrocytes in both D-galactose-induced and naturally aged rat models.
results_summary: SPD supplementation reduced age-related increases in reactive oxygen species, lipid peroxidation, and protein oxidation while boosting antioxidant levels and plasma membrane redox system activity in erythrocytes. The study suggests SPD improves redox status and membrane function in aging rats but calls for more research to confirm its therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Young male rats (4 months), D-galactose-induced aging model rats, and naturally aged rats (22 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spermidine improves endothelial function, reduces inflammation, and enhances mitophagy in lupus-prone mice.
results_summary: Spermidine treatment prevented endothelial dysfunction, reduced inflammatory markers, and increased parkin levels (a mitophagy marker) in lupus-prone mice, without affecting lupus phenotypes.
population_specificity: Female lupus-prone (MRL/lpr) and healthy control (MRL/MpJ) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a hydrogel loaded with spermidine-modified nanoparticles could provide multimodal therapeutic effects (antibacterial, ROS scavenging, anti-inflammatory) for treating periodontitis.
results_summary: The PH/M@S hydrogel demonstrated photothermal antibacterial activity, high ROS scavenging capacity, anti-inflammatory effects, and restored osteogenic differentiation potential in vitro and in a rat periodontitis model, effectively reducing bacterial load, inflammation, and alveolar bone resorption.
population_specificity: Rat model of periodontitis (in vivo) and lipopolysaccharide-stimulated macrophages (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adjunctive application of spermidine and calcium chloride gel improved outcomes in peri-implant mucositis treatment compared to mechanical debridement alone.
results_summary: Both test (spermidine gel + debridement) and control (debridement alone) groups showed statistically significant improvements, but no significant differences between them. However, the test group had fewer residual bleeding sites at 3 months.
population_specificity: 40 patients with peri-implant mucositis.
